7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (09:46): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905, do you like refbacks? if not, why not?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (09:51): 7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6, assuming you're talking about http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refback then no
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (09:52): because they're too easily open to abuse
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (09:52): HTTP header forgery can be used to trick a refback enabled site into accessing some other random site out there
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (09:53): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905, and then there is no link to the site and everything is well.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:53): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: why is it bad to do a GET to a random site out there?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (09:54): it's an attack surface on a server
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (09:54): for example, it's a trivial way to cause a DDOS
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (09:55): if you can trick 1000s of servers out there to issue a get request on one random site out there
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (09:55): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905, what do you recommend instead?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (09:56): there is no "Instead". the protocol is flawed all by itself.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (09:56): go back to the drawing board. ;)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (09:57): actually, given that I was able to explain a trivial DDOS scenario - and I'm not even a security expert, why isn't this documented on the wikipedia article?
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (09:57): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905, no. i mean: what do you recommend instead of using linkbacks?

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (10:00): oh I know - 7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6, here's your homework assignment in return for that answer, go update the wikipedia article to add a criticism section noting the trivial DDOS abuse of Refback enabled servers, with a <ref> cite to my statements above http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20111122#l-387 :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:00): it's already pretty trivial to cause a server to get a lot of GETs, that's not a particularly interesting security issue imho
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (10:00): or just add it to the existing Security issues section
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (10:01): nah, I call theoretical on that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:01): you can call what you like :-)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (10:01): worthy of documenting as a vulnerability introduced by implementing the protocol
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (10:01): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905, you are a clever and mean person.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:02): if you want to do a DDOS of the nature you describe it's far less work to just post a link on some popular site to some porn or a kitten, and include on that page a link to the victim site

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (10:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, if that were true, people would be doing it all the time on sites like http://cuteoverload.com/ but that doesn't appear to be happening.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:04): the reason they don't do it is that a bunch of GETs isn't a particularly interesting attack
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:04): same reason they don't do it with pingback, trackback, spam e-mail, etc
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:04): all of which are existing ways to do what you describe
